qas.question: What type of ice originates on land and floats out to sea?
What events have occurred in recent decades to the ice shelves surrounding Antarctica?
Along what area has there been more collapsing ice shelves?
What could the displacement of ice cause?
What weather event would offset loss of ice shelves?
Where did ice on land originate?

plausible_answers.text: a rise in global sea level

qas.question: What is the result of floating ice shelves melting from the land?
What does snow offset on the continent shelves?

plausible_answers.text: increased glacial outflow from the continental ice mass

qas.question: Where is the concern with regard to disruption of ice melts?

context: Melting of <a0_0><b5_0>floating ice shelves<b5_0/><a0_0/> (ice that originated on the land) does not in itself contribute much to sea-level rise (since the ice displaces only its own mass of water). However it is the <b7_0>outflow of the ice<b7_0/> from the land to form the ice shelf which causes <b6_0>a rise in global sea level<b6_0/>. This effect is offset by <a4_0>snow falling<a4_0/> back onto the continent. Recent decades have witnessed several dramatic <a1_0>collapses<a1_0/> of large ice shelves around the coast of Antarctica, especially along the <a2_0>Antarctic Peninsula<a2_0/>. Concerns have been raised that disruption of ice shelves may result in <b8_0>increased <a3_0>glacial outflow<a3_0/> from the continental ice mass<b8_0/>.
